case_name: Aravinda Mohan Sinha v. Prohlad Chandra Samanta

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 114 and 115 of 1970 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 114 115 of 1970 From the Judgment and Order dated the 28th

facts.text: Appeals arise from Judgment and Order dated 28th November 1969 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision Case Nos. 635 and 636 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Order dated the 28th November, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision Case Nos. 635 and 636 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeals brought by leave granted by High Court of Calcutta under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are brought by leave granted by the High Court of Calcutta under Article 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: On May 29, 1968 gold bars and sovereigns bearing foreign markings were seized from the respondents by customs officers, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Cr. A. No. 114 of 1970 On May 29, 1968 gold bars and sovereigns bearing foreign markings were seized from the respondents by customs officers, Calcutta.

facts.text: Respondents charged under section 135, Customs Act, 1962 for being in possession of goods liable to confiscation under section 111.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents were charged under section 135, Customs Act, 1962 for being in possession of goods which they had reason to believe to be liable to companyfiscation under section 111 of that Act.

facts.text: Goods alleged to be imported into India without requisite permit and without payment of duty, liable to confiscation under section 111(d).

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the goods were imported into India without the requisite permit and without payment of duty and were therefore liable to companyfiscation under section 111 d  of the Customs Act.

facts.text: Respondents charged under Rules 126P(1)(i) and 126P(2)(ii) of Defence of India Rules, 1962 for failure to make declaration of gold.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were also charged under Rules 126P 1  i  and 126P 2  ii  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, for failure to make a declaration in respect of the gold found in their possession.

facts.text: Respondents pleaded guilty to the charges but cited facts in extenuation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents pleaded guilty to the charges but cited facts in extenuation of the offences.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate, 8th Court, Calcutta convicted respondents but released them under section 4(1) of Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 on bond of Rs. 1000/- each with surety, for 2 years.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Presidency Magistrate, 8th Court, Calcutta, companyvicted them of the offences of which they were charged but he directed, on the faith of a report made by the Probation Officer, that they should be released under section 4 1  of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 on their executing a bond of Rs. 1000/- each with one surety in like amount, undertaking to appear and receive the sentence whenever called upon and to keep peace and be of good behaviour for a period of two years.

facts.text: Respondents are young boys normally engaged in agriculture.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents are young boys numbermally engaged in agriculture.

facts.text: Gold value about Rs. 7800/-, already confiscated in Customs proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The gold which was of the value of about Rs. 7800/- was already companyfiscated in the proceedings under the Customs Act.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs filed revision No. 635 of 1969 in Calcutta High Court, converted to appeal under section 11(2) Probation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, an Assistant Collector of Customs, filed on behalf of the Department a revision application  No. 635 of 1969  in the High Court of Calcutta against the judgment of the learned Magistrate. Later, it was companyverted into an appeal under section 11 2  of the Probation of Offenders Act,

facts.text: High Court disposed of three matters by common judgment reported in Aravinda Mohan Sinha v. Prohlad Chandra Samanta, AIR 1970 Cal 437.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of three matters by a companymon judgment which is reported in Aravinda Mohan Sinha v. Prohlad Chandra Samanta 1  Two out of these are before us the third, Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1970 is reported to be unready.

facts.text: On June 27, 1968 three bars of foreign gold were found on the person of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 115 of 1970 On June 27, 1968 three bars of foreign gold were found on the ,person of the respondent.

facts.text: In Cr A 115, respondent pleaded guilty, convicted by Presidency Magistrate 6th Court Calcutta under s135 Customs Act and Rules 126P(1)(i), 126P(2)(ii), fined Rs150 and Rs100 respectively, no separate sentence for latter rule.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded guilty at the trial whereupon the learned Presidency Magistrate, 6th Court, Calcutta companyvicted him under section 135, Customs Act, 1962 and under Rules 126 P  1  i  and 126 P  2  ii  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962. The respondent was sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 150 for the offence under the Customs Act and a fine of Rs. 100 for the offence under Rule 126 P  1  i . No separate sentence was imposed for the offence under Rule 126 P 2  ii .

facts.text: High Court in Cr A 115 confirmed conviction and sentence under Customs Act, but set aside conviction and sentence under Gold Control Rules holding no declaration needed for smuggled gold.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the High Court of Calcutta companyfirmed the companyviction and sentence under the Customs Act. Regarding the companytravention of the two Rules, the High Court held that numberdeclaration need have been made by the respondent to the Administrator, as the gold of which the respondent was in possession was smuggled gold and number legal gold. According to the High Court the legislature never expected that smuggled gold would be declared. The High Court therefore set aside the companyviction and sentence imposed on the respondent for companytravention of the Gold Control Rules.

facts.text: Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 received assent of President on May 16, 1958 and published in Gazette on May 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, received the assent of the President on May 16, 1958 and was published in the Gazette of India on May 19, 1958.

facts.text: Part XII-A Gold Control inserted in Defence of India Rules 1962 by GSR 89 dated January 9, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Part XII-A Gold Control  companysisting of Rules 126A to 126Z  was inserted in the Defence of India Rules, 1962 by G. S. R. 89 dated January 9, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Probation of Offenders Act applies to offences under Customs Act and Gold Control Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the appellants companytention that the probation of Offenders Act can have numberapplication to offences companysisting of the companytravantion of the Customs Act or the Gold Control Rules companytained in Part XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court disagrees with High Court in Cr A 115 that no declaration required for smuggled gold under Rule 126I.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberjustification in the scheme of the Rules for the view taken by the High Court that smuggled gold is number companyprehended within Rule 126P of the Gold Control Rules.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirms High Court judgment in Cr A 114 upholding probation release.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we companyfirm the judgment of the High Court.
These appeals are brought by leave granted by the High Court of Calcutta under Article 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, can apply to offences under the Customs Act, 1962 and to those under Part-XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, intituled Gold Control

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the Probation of Offenders Act,20 of 1958, can apply to offences under the Customs Act, 1962 and to those under Part-XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, intituled Gold Control.

issues.text: whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the respondents may be released on probation

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the respondents may be released on probation cannot be put in issue at this late stage because it was neither urged in the trial court nor before the High Court that by reason of the antecedents or the propensities of the respondents it was not expedient to extend to them the benefit of the Act.

issues.text: whether smuggled gold is comprehended within Rule 126P of the Gold Control Rules requiring declaration under Rule 126I

anchor.surface_text: We see no justification in the scheme of the Rules for the view taken by the High Court that smuggled gold is not comprehended within Rule 126P of the Gold Control Rules. The definition of gold in Rule 126A d is couched in wide terms and it does not make any distinction between smuggled gold and gold lawfully possessed.

arguments.claim: Probation of Offenders Act can have no application to offences consisting of the contravention of the Customs Act or the Gold Control Rules contained in Part XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the appellants contention that the probation of Offenders Act can have no application to offences consisting of the contravention of the Customs Act or the Gold Control Rules contained in Part XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mberapplication to offences companysisting of the companytravantion of the Customs Act or the Gold Control Rules companytained in Part XII-A of the De

arguments.court_reasoning: Words of section 4(1) wide and include such offences notwithstanding other laws; proportionality principle applies; reformative purpose of Act

arguments.claim: Though Rule 126P(2)(ii) prescribes minimum sentence of 6 months imprisonment, it cannot override provisions of Probation of Offenders Act making magistrate competent to release on probation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held in the matter under consideration that though Rule 126P 2 ii of the Defence of India Rules prescribes a minimum sentence of imprisonment for a term of not less than 6 months, it cannot override the provisions of the Probation of Offenders Act and therefore it was competent to the learned Magistrate to release the respondents under that Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ransom and the society may therefore look upon the release of offenders on probation as the triumph

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms judgment of High Court upholding probation release

arguments.claim: Words of section 4(1) of Probation of Offenders Act are wide and would evidently include offences under Customs Act and Gold Control Rules

anchor.surface_text: The words of section 4 1 of the Probation of offenders Act are wide and would evidently include offences under the customs Act and the Gold Control Rules.

arguments.claim: Broad principle that punishment must be proportioned to offence is of universal application save where statute bars judicial discretion in punishment or probation

anchor.surface_text: The broad principle that punishment must be proportioned to the offence is or ought to be of universal application save where the statute bars the exercise of judicial discretion either in awarding punishment or in releasing an offender on probation in lieu of sentencing him forthwith.

arguments.claim: Probation of Offenders Act is reformative measure to reclaim amateur offenders who can be rehabilitated if spared incarceration

anchor.surface_text: The Probation of Offenders Act is a reformative measure and its object is to reclaim amateur offenders who, if spared the indignity of incarceration, can be usefully rehabilitated in society.

arguments.claim: Probation applicable to food adulteration offences as in Isher Das v. State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: In Isher Das v. The State of Punjab the trial court released on Probation an offender who was convicted under section 7 1 of the Prevention

arguments.claim: No legal impediment to applying Probation Act to respondents given circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the respondents may be released on probation cannot be put in issue at this late stage because it was neither urged in the trial court nor before the High Court

arguments.claim: No declaration need be made for smuggled gold as legislature never expected smuggled gold to be declared

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the contravention of the two Rules, the High Court held that no declaration need have been made by the respondent to the Administrator, as the gold of which the respondent was in possession was smuggled gold and no legal gold. According to the High Court the legislature never expected that smuggled gold would be declared.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ment for a further period of a month and a half. Setting aside the order of the High Court this Cour

arguments.court_reasoning: No justification in scheme of Rules; definition of gold wide with no distinction

arguments.claim: Definition of gold in Rule 126A(d) couched in wide terms makes no distinction between smuggled and lawfully possessed gold

anchor.surface_text: The definition of gold in Rule 126A d is couched in wide terms and it does not make any distinction between smuggled gold and gold lawfully possessed.

arguments.claim: Legislative intention gathered from words used; definition carves no exception for smuggled gold

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the legislature must be gathered primarily and principally from the words used by it and the definition of gold carves out no exception in favour of smuggled gold.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Rules imposes declaration obligation on all possessors including smugglers; cannot leave smugglers untouched

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, if the intention of the legislature as reflected in the scheme of a law is to control the meaning of the words used in a particular Section or Rule, it strikes us as surprising that the obligation to declare gold should be imposed on lawful possessors of gold but should leave untouched the possession by smugglers or their agents of gold smuggled into the country.

arguments.claim: Same word 'gold' used throughout Part XII-A must receive same meaning

anchor.surface_text: The word gold is used at several places in Part XIIA and it is a well-recognised rule of construction that the same word should receive the same meaning in a context.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Gold Control Rules covers gold in any form whether lawfully possessed or otherwise

anchor.surface_text: Part XII-A Gold Control consisting of Rules 126A to 126Z was inserted in the Defence of India Rules, 1962 by G. S. R. 89 dated January 9, 1963.

holdings.text: The Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, can apply to offences under the Customs Act, 1962 and to those under Part-XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, intituled Gold Control.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the appellants contention that the probation of Offenders Act can have numberapplication to offences companysisting of the companytravantion of the Customs Act or the Gold Control Rules companytained in Part XII-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of section 4(1) are wide enough to include such offences notwithstanding other laws; proportionality of punishment applies universally unless barred; reformative purpose of Act supports application; precedents like Isher Das affirm.

holdings.text: There is no legal impediment to applying the Probation of Offenders Act to the respondents and their release on probation is confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the respondents may be released on probation cannot be put in issue at this late stage because it was neither urged in the trial court nor before the High Court that by reason of the antecedents or the propensities of the respondents it was number expedient to extend to them the benefit of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No challenge to antecedents or propensities raised earlier; Magistrate exercised discretion based on Probation Officer report; High Court upheld; no reason to interfere.

holdings.text: Smuggled gold is comprehended within Rule 126P of the Gold Control Rules and requires declaration under Rule 126I.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberjustification in the scheme of the Rules for the view taken by the High Court that smuggled gold is number companyprehended within Rule 126P of the Gold Control Rules. The definition of gold in Rule 126A d is couched in wide terms and it does number make any distinction between smuggled gold and gold lawfully possessed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide definition of gold in Rule 126A(d) includes all gold without distinction; legislative intent from plain words and scheme requires declaration by all possessors; consistent meaning of 'gold' throughout Part XII-A; purposive control of all gold possession.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court upholding the Magistrate's order releasing respondents on probation under section 4(1) of the Probation of Offenders Act in Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1970 is confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we companyfirm the judgment of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held that minimum sentence under Rule 126P(2)(ii) does not override Probation Act; discretion properly exercised.

holdings.text: The High Court's setting aside of conviction and sentence under Gold Control Rules in Criminal Appeal No. 115 of 1970 is reversed as smuggled gold requires declaration.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore unable to agree with the High Court that the respondent was number liable to make under Rule 1261 a declaration as to the gold in his possession and that therefore Rule 126P is number attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme and definition cover smuggled gold; no exception carved out; overturns High Court's purposive exclusion.
